text: I'm at the Chernobyl nuclear power
station in Ukraine and behind me is
reactor number four which was the scene
of the world's worst nuclear accident
back in April 1986 now in the months
after the explosion the reactor was
given an emergency covering of concrete
but in the decade since then that
started to corrode and has been in
danger of collapse so the international
community has come up with an
extraordinary plan to build this vast
structure a kind of arch or shield what
they call a safe confinement that's
being built just beside the reactor but
shortly will be slid on Rails over it to
try to keep the place safe for at least
a hundred years this is one of the rails
the structure will roll along when it's
ready to be moved into position now to
come this close I've had to put on
safety equipment but it gives me the
chance to show you a couple of features
up above me you can see this tangle of
girders that's part of a double skinned
the structure will have to help control
temperature and humidity and if you look
at the end wall that rather strange
shape that's actually designed to slide
over the reactor building and provide a
tight fit and if you look right up at
the ceiling those rails up there from
there cranes will hang they'll be
remotely controlled so that when the
structure the shield is over the reactor
then there's robotically controlled
cranes we'll be able to start
dismantling the most dangerous parts of
the building now an obvious question if
you're this close to the reactor how on
earth do stay safe from radiation well
for a start this part of the site was
decontaminated before this construction
work began and then a protective wall
was built between this site and the
reactor and that reduces any radiation
received by people here if you worked a
normal shift here for about a year you'd
receive the
equivalent dose you get through a chest
x-ray
